qas.question: Before Einstein, electromagnetic radiation was considered to behave as what?
What terms describe different types of radiation?
What is the energy transferred by a wave in a given time called?
What other types of wave besides light has its own intensity?
Prior to Einstein's work, light behavior was modeled as what?
What is the name for the amount of energy transfered by a wave in a given time?
What portion of the photoelectric effect was in disagreement with the believed description of light behavior?
What does it mean for a light source to be more intense than another?

answers.text: gives out more energy per unit time and per unit space

qas.question: What terms describe the same types of radiation?
What is the energy lost by a wave in a long time called?
What other types of wave besides light doesn't have its own intensity?
What is the name for the amount of energy disappearing by a wave in a given time?

plausible_answers.text: gives out more energy per unit time and per unit space

qas.question: What does it mean for a light source to be equally intense?

context: Prior to Einstein's paper, electromagnetic radiation such as visible light was considered to behave as <a0_0><a4_0>a wave<a4_0/><a0_0/>: hence the use of the terms <a1_0><b8_0>"frequency" and "wavelength"<b8_0/><a1_0/> to characterise different types of radiation. The energy transferred by a wave in a given time is called its <a2_0><a5_0><b9_0>intensity<b9_0/><a5_0/><a2_0/>. The light from a theatre spotlight is more intense than the light from a domestic lightbulb; that is to say that the spotlight <a7_0><b12_0>gives out more energy per unit time and per unit space<b12_0/><a7_0/>(and hence consumes more electricity) than the ordinary bulb, even though the colour of the light might be very similar. Other waves, such as <a3_0><b10_0>sound<b10_0/><a3_0/> or the waves crashing against a seafront, also have their own <b11_0>intensity<b11_0/>. However, <a6_0>the energy account<a6_0/> of the photoelectric effect didn't seem to agree with the wave description of light.
